title: Will the People's Republic of China's (PRC's) military expenditure as a percentage of GDP be greater in 2021 than it was in 2019?
preds: I'm very, very glad to see other people disagreeing with the crowd's degree of confidence on this one. Staying halfway between the agnostic 50% and the 96% of the crowd.

Previous rational still stands - https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1345789 Mathematically (assuming the some numbers reported by the Global times a while back), 8% GDP growth was large enough for the expenditure to GDP ratio to decrease. However after being unable to reconcile the SIPRI data and the Global Times numbers, I think the China's solid GDP numbers will drive this ratio down regardless of their spend this year.

Genuinely baffled at the crowds confidence on this one. I think it's more likely than not, but certainly not a 98% chance, especially when we're forecasting so much in the dark. Give the article I cited at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1331996 it seems more than possible this could go the other way as GDP has been more resilient than expected, it's pretty late in the game, so a change now is almost meaningless, but I'm not comfortable giving the overall odds more than a 2-1 chance.

But now, the reported SIPRI data is now showing a reduction in this metric from 2018 to 2019 (1.7395% in 2018), which contradicts the GT numbers, and adds a bunch of doubt to my position.  The target of 8% is only valid if the GT reported growth is correct, if it is closer to 1.3% (selected as the growth in the metric from 2019-2020), the above formula gives 2.56%, a number so low it was almost passed in 2020. Given the uncertainty of estimates for both military spending and GDP forecasts, this is difficult to predict. However, the most recent data showing stronger than expected Chinese GDP growth in the first half of 2021 suggests that the crowd is overconfident here. Especially given that military share of GDP did not increase in the three years before the pandemic.

"While policy makers remain comfortably on pace to hit their full-year growth domestic product target of at least 6%—first half GDP growth was 12.7% year over year—further deterioration in these two sectors [ Real estate investment and construction] could change the calculus for leaders in Beijing." https://www.wsj.com/articles/chinas-economic-recovery-is-looking-gloomier-11631683862?mod=article_inline The crowds confidence from the start has confused me on this question. https://sipri.org/media/press-release/2021/world-military-spending-rises-almost-2-trillion-2020 Even though China's GDP growth looks like it will be lower than some initial forecasts for this year, having their military burden decrease last year means it has to grow disproportionally this year to make the ratio higher than 2019 and resolve yes to the question. 2021 is expecting a 6.8% increase in military spending and most GDP forecasts are still over 8%.  Sooo..... if the burden decreased in 2020, and again in 2021, then the percentage has to be lower... I think....

So the 209.2 could really be 292.9 BN USD, meaning the real number could be ~1.76% of GDP. It seems that 40% extra is pretty consistent in SIPRI's estimations.
So, we've got 2 variables... how much above the official numbers will SIPRI state actual spending to be?... and what will actual GDP growth be?...

+25. 2020 came in at 1.7498 compared to 1.7278 in 2019. The latest release shows that SIPRI switched all their numbers to the new methodology, so this confirmed we will be comparing like to like, which was one reason I was at 45% instead of 50% because I initially believed this might be a tossup. If we just look at the publicly available information, China announced their 2020 military budget would grow by 6.6%. SIPRI says some of China's military spending doesn't show up in the actual budget, but for simplicity lets assume that it also grew by 6.6%. Looking at China's GDP growth, 2020 grew by 2.99% (note, I'm using reported GDP numbers at the FRED link below, not adjusted for inflation which I think is necessary since from what I can tell Chinese military spending growth announcements also are not inflation adjusted). So if we take the 2019 number of 1.7278% (which is military spending over GDP) and increase the military spending by 6.6% and the GDP by 2.99% (or in other words multiply 1.7278*1.066/1.0299) you get 1.7884, which is much larger than the 2020 number reported of 1.7498. If you assume the 2.99% GDP growth is accurate the actual 2020 spending number implies a military spending growth of only 4.3%. So in other words, without spending hours digging into the methodology I don't know if any of us can make rhyme or reason of these numbers, and in my opinion it's probably safer to default to the base rate, which shows that since 2007, for 9 out of 13 of the years (excluding 2019) military spending has been a larger share of GDP than it was in 2019. That's about 70%, so that's what I'm adjusting to. China's 2020 GDP was $14.7 trillion USD. China has set the goal of a 6% increase over this number for 2021, which would be $15.582 trillion USD. Economists estimate an increase of 8.4% over 2020, which would be $15.9348 trillion USD. China has set their 2021 military budget at $202 billion USD. SIPRI explains there is a difference between the official military budget and what SIPRI includes in "military expenditures" (detailed here: https://www.sipri.org/databases/milex/sources-and-methods#definition-of-military-expenditure). SIPRI explains the difference is usually a 50% increase over the official military budget. 1.5 times $202 billion would be a "goal" of $303 billion for 2021. The "6% increase" GDP goal China has set would result in a mil expenditure of 1.9446%. The 8.4% increase economists have forecast would result in a mil expenditure of 1.9015%. I'm assuming the 1.5 multiple holds true for 2021. Therefore, for the 2021 mil expenditure to be greater than 2019's mil expenditure (which was 1.8886%), China's 2021 GDP would need to be greater than $16.0436 trillion USD, an increase over 2020's GDP of 9.1403%. Thus, if China overachieves its own goal of 6% GDP growth by more than 50% (to 9.14%; something I don't expect is feasible), mil expenditure as a percentage of GDP will be less than 2019's (1.8886%). Otherwise, expect this percentage to rise to between 1.9015% and 1.9446%. I have done rough calculations based on SIRPI numbers to determine how sensitive military expenditures as a share of GDP to a 1% change in GDP. The ratio of 5 to 1, i.e. a 1% increase in GDP will reduce military expenditure as a % of GDP by 0.2%, keeping the USD number of military expenditures constant.
In 2019 GDP growth was 6% and if this year it will be 7% then assuming mean reversion to 1.91% of military spending to GDP, we need to adjust it lower by 0.2% to 1.89%. This is also assuming that China will stick to the same logic of military spending as they did in previous years and will not decide to boost or reduce for some geopolitical or domestic reasons. Therefore the answer then narrows down to: will China's GDP growth is going to be above or below 7% in 2021? This is a close call  at this stage. there are a few more interesting observations:
/even in that very final period of the cold war-era and the early 1990s, China has never spent more than 2.5% of GDP (or, at least, that's what was estimated amid a lack of figures), less than half of what the U.S. spent for most of the 1990s. China's persistent spending could thus be seen as a long-term effort to catch up with the U.S., although the U.S. will rather see this as a new era of arms race sparked by China.
/between 2004 and 2019, China seems to have an average goal of 2.0% of GDP, but adapts its spending to the economic cycle also: in order to avoid negative inflationary (cost-driving) effects, the spending regularly falls behind 2.0% in an economic upswing and boom time, while in economic crises (2003-05; 2009; probably 2020 also) the Chinese government increases "deficit spending" on military projects contrarian to cycles, in order to keep up GDP and employment, steel, energy production etc., and preserve the long-term real estate bubble.
Once the crisis is over - and 2021 will prove to be such a year - and the economy is growing at a normal pace, spending tends to be cut down (or, at least, does not keep the same pace as the rest of the economy), for several reasons maybe ( see 2010-12).
